prompt_text:
Create a Facebook post announcing an event for [ORGANIZATION NAME].

BEFORE YOU START
Have this information ready.

Required:
- [EVENT NAME]
- [DATE]
- [TIME]
- [LOCATION or VIRTUAL LINK]
- [COST or FREE]
- [TARGET AUDIENCE] (who it’s for)
- [BENEFIT/OUTCOME] (what they’ll gain)
- [REGISTRATION LINK or FACEBOOK EVENT URL]
- [TONE: FORMAL / WARM / CASUAL] (choose one)

Optional (include only if applicable):
- [SPEAKERS/HIGHLIGHTS or KEY TOPICS]
- [ACCESSIBILITY FEATURES]
- [CHILDCARE]
- [LANGUAGE INTERPRETATION]
- [PARKING/TRANSIT]
- [COVID/SAFETY]
- [DEADLINE / LIMITED SEATS / EARLY-BIRD ENDS DATE]
- [PARTNERS TO TAG] and/or [VENUE TO TAG]
- [SPOKESPERSON NAME/TITLE] (if you want a sign-off—otherwise write “none”)
- [CONTACT EMAIL/PHONE]
- [UTM = Yes/No] and, if Yes, paste [UTM PARAMETERS] to append to the link

QUICK-FILL WORKSHEET (copy, fill, and paste below)
[ORGANIZATION NAME]:
[EVENT NAME]:
[DATE]:
[TIME]:
[LOCATION or VIRTUAL LINK]:
[COST]:
[TARGET AUDIENCE]:
[BENEFIT/OUTCOME]:
[SPEAKERS/HIGHLIGHTS]:
[ACCESSIBILITY FEATURES]:
[CHILDCARE]:
[LANGUAGE INTERPRETATION]:
[PARKING/TRANSIT]:
[COVID/SAFETY]:
[REGISTRATION LINK or FACEBOOK EVENT URL]:
[UTM = Yes/No]:
[UTM PARAMETERS if Yes]:
[DEADLINE / LIMITED SEATS / EARLY-BIRD ENDS]:
[PARTNERS TO TAG]:
[VENUE TO TAG]:
[TONE: FORMAL / WARM / CASUAL]:
[SPOKESPERSON NAME/TITLE or “none”]:
[CONTACT EMAIL/PHONE]:

POST REQUIREMENTS

Length & format:
- 100–150 words (caption)
- Mobile-first: Put What/When/Where/Cost in the first 2 lines, before “See more”
- Short, scannable sentences and line breaks

Content structure (in this order):
1) Hook (Line 1): Lead with benefit or urgency (not “Join us for…”).
2) Essential details (Lines 1–2, visible before “See more”):
   - [EVENT NAME] | [DATE] | [TIME] | [LOCATION or VIRTUAL LINK] | [COST]
3) Why it matters (1 sentence): Who it’s for + key benefit.
4) Brief description (1–2 sentences): [SPEAKERS/HIGHLIGHTS or KEY TOPICS]. Add only relevant logistics: [ACCESSIBILITY], [CHILDCARE], [LANGUAGE INTERPRETATION], [PARKING/TRANSIT], [COVID/SAFETY].
5) Clear CTA: Strong verb + [REGISTRATION LINK or FACEBOOK EVENT URL]. If [UTM = Yes], append [UTM PARAMETERS]. Prompt readers to tap “Interested” or “Going.”
6) Ethical urgency (only if true): [DEADLINE / LIMITED SEATS / EARLY-BIRD ENDS DATE].

Formatting:
- Emojis: 0–2 max (use only if they add clarity/warmth)
- Hashtags: 1–3 relevant, at the end
- Tags: Include [PARTNERS TO TAG] and [VENUE TO TAG] if provided
- Avoid: Jargon, unexplained acronyms, clichés, excessive exclamation points

Tone:
- Choose [FORMAL], [WARM] (default), or [CASUAL] and keep it consistent

Voice & sign-off:
- Use organizational voice. No signature unless [SPOKESPERSON NAME/TITLE] is provided.

ALSO PROVIDE

1) Image suggestion:
- One easy-to-capture concept for a small team (pick one that fits the event), e.g.:
  - Photo of past attendees engaging with a speaker
  - Speaker headshot with a short quote overlay
  - Simple text graphic with event name/date/time/location
  - Relevant action shot at the venue or program site
- Include 20–30 word alt-text for accessibility.

2) Pinned first comment (30–50 words):
- Add helpful logistics (agenda, parking/transit, what to bring) and a contact for questions: [CONTACT EMAIL/PHONE].

3) A/B test variation:
- Provide a second caption with a different opening hook only. Keep all other details identical so you can isolate hook performance.

OUTPUT FORMAT (return in this order)
- Caption Version A (100–150 words)
- Caption Version B (different hook; 100–150 words)
- Image suggestion (1–2 sentences)
- Alt-text (20–30 words)
- Pinned first comment (30–50 words)
- Posting tips (3–5 bullets)

QUALITY CHECKLIST (the AI should)
- Put What/When/Where/Cost in lines 1–2 (before “See more”)
- Use short, human sentences with clear CTA and honest urgency
- Keep emojis ≤2 and hashtags 1–3, relevant only
- Tag partners/venue when provided
- Avoid walls of text, jargon, and clichés

POSTING TIPS (include in output)
- Post 6–9am or 12–2pm local; adjust using your Facebook Insights for when your audience is most active
- Cross-post from the Facebook Event page and tag venue/partners to expand reach
- Monitor and reply to comments in the first hour to boost distribution

EXAMPLE INPUT
[ORGANIZATION NAME]: Riverside Food Bank
[EVENT NAME]: Community Nutrition Workshop
[DATE]: Saturday, March 15
[TIME]: 10am–12pm
[LOCATION]: Riverside Community Center, 123 Main St
[COST]: Free
[TARGET AUDIENCE]: Parents and caregivers
[BENEFIT/OUTCOME]: Learn to prepare healthy meals on a budget
[SPEAKERS/HIGHLIGHTS]: Registered dietitian Maria Santos, cooking demo, free recipe booklet
[ACCESSIBILITY FEATURES]: ASL interpretation available
[REGISTRATION LINK or FACEBOOK EVENT URL]: www.riversidefoodbank.org/workshop
[UTM = Yes/No]: No
[DEADLINE / LIMITED SEATS / EARLY-BIRD ENDS]: Limited to 30 participants
[PARTNERS TO TAG]: Riverside Community Center
[VENUE TO TAG]: Riverside Community Center
[TONE]: WARM
[SPOKESPERSON NAME/TITLE]: none
[CONTACT EMAIL/PHONE]: workshops@riversidefoodbank.org or 555-0123

HOW TO USE THIS PROMPT
1) Copy this entire prompt.
2) Replace everything in [BRACKETS] with your info. If something doesn’t apply, write “none” or delete that item.
3) If [UTM = Yes], paste your [UTM PARAMETERS]; if No, the AI should use a clean link.
4) Choose one [TONE] and delete the others.
5) Paste into your AI tool and generate.

NEED A SIMPLER VERSION?
Quick Start:
Create a 100–150 word Facebook post for [ORGANIZATION] announcing [EVENT NAME] on [DATE] at [TIME] at [LOCATION or VIRTUAL LINK]. Cost: [FREE/PRICE]. Audience: [TARGET AUDIENCE]. Benefit: [BENEFIT/OUTCOME]. Include a strong CTA to register at [LINK]. Use a warm tone and put What/When/Where/Cost in the first two lines.

scenarios.name: Large Established Org
scenarios.description: Urban, citywide arts nonprofit with major institutional partners and broad family audience.

values.EVENT NAME: Family Day at the Grand Museum
values.LOCATION or VIRTUAL LINK: Grand Museum of Art, 455 Museum Way, Harbor City
values.TARGET AUDIENCE: Families with children ages 3–12; museum members and general public
values.BENEFIT/OUTCOME: Hands-on art-making, performances, and free admission that spark creativity and connection.
values.SPEAKERS/HIGHLIGHTS or KEY TOPICS: Studio stations; youth dance performance at 11:30am; gallery scavenger hunt; first 200 kids receive art kits.
values.ACCESSIBILITY FEATURES: Elevator access; quiet/sensory-friendly hour 10–11am; large-print guides available.
values.CHILDCARE: Caregivers must remain with children (no drop-off).
values.LANGUAGE INTERPRETATION: Spanish and Mandarin volunteers at welcome desk.
values.PARKING/TRANSIT: Garage parking validated up to 2 hours; near Metro Line A, Museum Way stop.
values.COVID/SAFETY: Please stay home if you’re ill; hand sanitizer available throughout.

values.SPOKESPERSON NAME/TITLE: Alicia Moreno, Director of Community Programs
values.SPEAKERS/HIGHLIGHTS: Hands-on studio stations; youth dance at 11:30am; scavenger hunt; art kits for first 200 kids.
values.DEADLINE / LIMITED SEATS / EARLY-BIRD EN: Art kits limited to first 200 kids; RSVP recommended.
values.SPOKESPERSON NAME/TITLE or \u201cnone\u2: Alicia Moreno, Director of Community Programs

values.LOCATION: Grand Museum of Art, 455 Museum Way, Harbor City

outputs.content:
**Caption Version A**

Ensure your family's drinking water is safe! Join us for **Well Water Testing Day | Saturday, April 12, 2025 | 9:00am–12:00pm | Pine Ridge Grange Hall, 48 County Rd B, Pine Ridge, WI | Free.** This event is for rural households using private wells in Pine County, offering free screening for common contaminants and guidance on next steps.

We'll have on-site nitrate/arsenic screening and a county Extension agent available for Q&A. Free test kits are available for the first 50 households. The venue has a ramp entrance, accessible restrooms, and seating. Kids are welcome with a coloring and activity table. Spanish interpretation is available upon request. Parking is available in our free gravel lot, with overflow at Pine Ridge Elementary (0.2 mi walk). Masks are optional, and curbside sample drop-off is available.

Learn more and find sample collection instructions at https://pineridgecc.org/wellwater. Tap "Interested" or "Going" to stay updated!

Free kits are limited to the first 50 households, while supplies last. Don't forget to bring a 16oz water sample in a clean jar!

@UWExtensionPineCounty @PineRidgeHealthDept @PineRidgeGrange
#WellWaterTesting #PineCounty #CommunitySafety

**Caption Version B**

Wondering about your well water quality? Get answers at our **Well Water Testing Day | Saturday, April 12, 2025 | 9:00am–12:00pm | Pine Ridge Grange Hall, 48 County Rd B, Pine Ridge, WI | Free.** This event is for rural households using private wells in Pine County, offering free screening for common contaminants and guidance on next steps to keep your family’s drinking water safe.

We’ll offer on-site nitrate/arsenic screening and a county Extension agent for your questions. The first 50 households will also receive free test kits. For your comfort, we have a ramp entrance, accessible restrooms, and seating. Kids can enjoy a coloring and activity table. Spanish interpretation is available upon request. Parking options include a free gravel lot onsite and overflow at Pine Ridge Elementary (0.2 mi walk). Masks are optional, and curbside sample drop-off is available.

For details and sample collection instructions, visit https://pineridgecc.org/wellwater. Be sure to tap "Interested" or "Going"!

Free kits are limited to the first 50 households, while supplies last. Remember to bring a 16oz water sample in a clean jar!

@UWExtensionPineCounty @PineRidgeHealthDept @PineRidgeGrange
#WellWaterSafety #DrinkingWater #PineRidge

**Image suggestion**
A simple text graphic with the event title "Well Water Testing Day," the date "Saturday, April 12, 2025," time "9:00am–12:00pm," and location "Pine Ridge Grange Hall."

**Alt-text**
A graphic announcing "Well Water Testing Day" on April 12, 2025, from 9 AM to 12 PM at Pine Ridge Grange Hall, with info about free testing for Pine County residents.

**Pinned first comment**
Remember to bring a 16oz water sample collected from your well in a clean jar! We'll have a county Extension agent on-site. Parking is available in our gravel lot, with overflow at Pine Ridge Elementary. For questions, contact info@pineridgecc.org or 715-555-0109.

**Posting tips**
*   Post 6–9am or 12–2pm local; adjust using your Facebook Insights for when your audience is most active
*   Cross-post from the Facebook Event page and tag venue/partners to expand reach
*   Monitor and reply to comments in the first hour to boost distribution

evaluation.reasoning: The output demonstrates good tone and includes all required elements, but critically fails the core formatting requirement: both captions exceed 200 words (far beyond the 100-150 word limit) and bury essential details in dense paragraphs instead of using mobile-first line breaks. This makes the posts unusable without significant editing, undermining their practical value for a small nonprofit.
strengths: Warm, accessible tone appropriate for rural community audience
Both hooks (Version A: 'Ensure your family's drinking water is safe' and Version B: 'Wondering about your well water quality?') are benefit-focused and avoid the 'Join us' cliché
Comprehensive inclusion of all logistics (accessibility, childcare, parking, Spanish interpretation, COVID options)
Strong CTAs with specific instructions to tap 'Interested' or 'Going'
Pinned comment effectively consolidates practical details and contact info
Image suggestion is realistic for a small volunteer-led organization
Alt-text is descriptive and meets accessibility standards
Appropriate partner/venue tagging and hashtag usage (3 relevant tags)
weaknesses: Critical formatting failure: Captions are ~230 words each, 50%+ over the 100-150 word limit specified in the prompt
Does not follow mobile-first structure: Essential details are formatted as dense prose paragraphs rather than scannable lines with breaks before 'See more' cutoff
Logistics overload: Includes every optional detail in the main caption, creating a wall of text that would perform poorly on mobile Facebook
Repetitive phrasing: 'Free kits are limited to the first 50 households, while supplies last' appears twice in each caption (once in body, once at end)
Missing emoji usage: Prompt allows 0-2 emojis for clarity/warmth; none used despite warm tone and family-focused audience
Version B hook is weaker (question format less urgent than Version A's direct benefit statement)
No strategic prioritization: Treats all logistics as equally important rather than highlighting the most compelling elements (free testing, Extension agent expertise)

outputs.content:
# Caption Version A

**Is your well water safe to drink?**

Well Water Testing Day | Saturday, April 12, 2025 | 9am–12pm | Pine Ridge Grange Hall, 48 County Rd B, Pine Ridge, WI | Free for Pine County residents

If your rural household relies on a private well, get free screening for common contaminants and guidance on keeping your family's drinking water safe.

On-site nitrate and arsenic screening, county Extension agent Q&A, and free test kits for the first 50 households. Kids welcome—we'll have a coloring and activity table. Spanish interpretation and curbside sample drop-off available. Accessible entrance, restrooms, and seating. Free parking onsite; overflow at Pine Ridge Elementary (0.2 mi).

**Learn more and register:** https://pineridgecc.org/wellwater

Mark yourself "Going" so we can plan! 

⚠️ Free kits limited to first 50 households. Bring a 16oz water sample in a clean jar.

#WellWaterSafety #PineCounty #DrinkingWater

@UWExtensionPineCounty @PineRidgeHealthDept @PineRidgeGrange

---

# Caption Version B

**Protecting your family starts with clean water.**

Well Water Testing Day | Saturday, April 12, 2025 | 9am–12pm | Pine Ridge Grange Hall, 48 County Rd B, Pine Ridge, WI | Free for Pine County residents

Rural households with private wells: get free screening for common contaminants and expert guidance on next steps to keep your family's drinking water safe.

On-site nitrate and arsenic screening, county Extension agent Q&A, and free test kits for the first 50 households. Kids welcome—we'll have a coloring and activity table. Spanish interpretation and curbside sample drop-off available. Accessible entrance, restrooms, and seating. Free parking onsite; overflow at Pine Ridge Elementary (0.2 mi).

**Learn more and register:** https://pineridgecc.org/wellwater

Tap "Going" to save your spot!

⚠️ Free kits limited to first 50 households. Bring a 16oz water sample in a clean jar.

#WellWaterSafety #PineCounty #DrinkingWater

@UWExtensionPineCounty @PineRidgeHealthDept @PineRidgeGrange

---

# Image Suggestion

Photo of a volunteer or Extension agent holding a water testing kit next to a jar of well water, with the Pine Ridge Grange Hall visible in the background or a simple text graphic displaying "Well Water Testing Day | April 12 | Free."

**Alt-text:** County Extension agent holds water testing kit and sample jar at Pine Ridge Grange Hall; text overlay reads "Well Water Testing Day, April 12, 9am-12pm, Free for Pine County residents."

---

# Pinned First Comment

**What to bring:** 16oz water sample in a clean jar (if you want on-site testing). Free test kits available for first 50 households while supplies last. Parking in the free gravel lot; overflow at Pine Ridge Elementary. Request accommodations 72 hours in advance. Questions? Contact info@pineridgecc.org or 715-555-0109.

---

# Posting Tips

- **Post between 6–9am or 12–2pm local time** for best visibility; check your Facebook Insights to refine timing based on when your audience is most active.
- **Create a Facebook Event** and cross-post this caption from the event page to boost reach and allow RSVPs.
- **Tag all partners** (@UWExtensionPineCounty, @PineRidgeHealthDept, @PineRidgeGrange) to expand your audience and encourage shares.
- **Reply to comments within the first hour** to signal engagement to Facebook's algorithm and increase distribution.
- **Share to relevant local groups** (with admin permission) like Pine County community pages, homesteading groups, or parenting groups to reach rural households.

evaluation.reasoning: This output demonstrates strong adherence to the prompt template with appropriate warm tone, comprehensive logistics, and actionable CTAs. The captions are well-structured for mobile viewing with essential details front-loaded. Minor weaknesses include slightly exceeding word count and one emoji usage that could be reconsidered, but overall this is publication-ready content a small nonprofit could use immediately.
strengths: Excellent mobile-first formatting with What/When/Where/Cost clearly visible before 'See more' cutoff
Strong, benefit-focused hooks in both versions that avoid generic 'Join us' language ('Is your well water safe to drink?' and 'Protecting your family starts with clean water')
Comprehensive inclusion of all accessibility and logistics details (Spanish interpretation, curbside option, parking, childcare) without overwhelming the reader
Effective A/B test structure that isolates only the hook variable while keeping all other content identical for valid testing
Practical, context-specific posting tips that go beyond generic advice (e.g., suggesting sharing to homesteading/parenting groups)
Well-crafted pinned comment that adds value with 'what to bring' details and accommodation request timeline
Appropriate partner tagging and ethical urgency messaging about limited kits
weaknesses: Word count slightly exceeds the 100-150 word target (approximately 155-160 words in each caption)
The warning emoji (⚠️) may not render consistently across all devices and could be replaced with text-based urgency
The phrase 'Mark yourself Going' is slightly awkward; 'Tap Going' or 'Click Going' would be more natural
Alt-text could be slightly more concise (currently 31 words, target was 20-30)

outputs.content:

💧 Keep your family’s drinking water safe with free well screening.
Well Water Testing Day | Saturday, April 12, 2025 | 9:00am–12:00pm | Pine Ridge Grange Hall, 48 County Rd B, Pine Ridge, WI | Free

RSVP or learn more: https://pineridgecc.org/wellwater. Tap Interested or Going. @UWExtensionPineCounty @PineRidgeHealthDept @PineRidgeGrange

Bring a 16oz water sample in a clean jar. Free kits while supplies last. #WellWater #PineCounty

- Caption Version B (different hook; 100–150 words)
💧 What’s in your well water? Find out for free.
Well Water Testing Day | Saturday, April 12, 2025 | 9:00am–12:00pm | Pine Ridge Grange Hall, 48 County Rd B, Pine Ridge, WI | Free

For rural Pine County households using private wells. Get screening for common contaminants and clear next steps.

On-site nitrate/arsenic screening and Q&A with county Extension agents. Free test kits for the first 50 households.

Ramp entrance and accessible restrooms; seating available. Kids welcome—coloring/activity table. Spanish interpretation and other accommodations by request (72 hours ahead).

Free gravel lot; overflow at Pine Ridge Elementary (0.2 mi). Masks optional; curbside sample drop-off available.

RSVP or learn more: https://pineridgecc.org/wellwater. Tap Interested or Going. @UWExtensionPineCounty @PineRidgeHealthDept @PineRidgeGrange

Bring a 16oz water sample in a clean jar. Free kits while supplies last. #WellWater #PineCounty

- Image suggestion (1–2 sentences)
Action shot at Pine Ridge Grange Hall: a staff member dips a test strip into a resident’s clear jar of well water at a labeled screening table, with a kids’ coloring station softly visible behind.

- Alt-text (20–30 words)
A staffer tests a clear jar of well water with a strip at a community table. Informational flyers, simple signage, and a small kids’ coloring area appear in the background.

Agenda: sample drop-off opens 9:00; ongoing screening and Extension Q&A; last samples 11:45. Parking in gravel lot; overflow at Pine Ridge Elementary (0.2 mi). Bring a clean 16oz water sample. Questions: info@pineridgecc.org or 715-555-0109.

- Posting tips (3–5 bullets)
- Post 6–9am or 12–2pm local; adjust using your Facebook Insights for when your audience is most active

evaluation.reasoning: The output successfully delivers warm, community-focused messaging with excellent structure and practical components. However, both captions exceed the 150-word limit (approximately 155-160 words each), and the density of logistics in the middle paragraphs creates readability challenges that contradict the prompt's emphasis on scannable, mobile-first formatting.
strengths: Strong, benefit-focused hooks that avoid the generic 'Join us' opening—both versions lead with safety/curiosity
Essential details (What/When/Where/Cost) are correctly front-loaded in lines 1-2 before the 'See more' fold
Warm, accessible tone throughout that feels genuinely community-oriented rather than institutional
Excellent pinned comment that adds logistical value (agenda timeline, parking specifics, what to bring)
Image suggestion is realistic for a small volunteer team and includes thoughtful, descriptive alt-text
Proper restraint with emojis (1 only) and hashtags (2 relevant ones)
All required tags included correctly, and CTA is clear with dual action ('RSVP' + 'Tap Interested or Going')
Posting tips are practical and include a smart event-day reminder strategy
weaknesses: Word count violation: both captions run 155-160 words instead of the required 100-150 maximum
Middle section becomes a wall of text with accessibility, childcare, parking, and COVID details stacked in two dense paragraphs—contradicts 'short, scannable sentences and line breaks' requirement
The 'bring a 16oz water sample' instruction appears at the very end after the CTA, but this is critical prep information that should be more prominent or in the pinned comment only
Minor redundancy: 'Free kits while supplies last' repeats the 'first 50 households' urgency already stated earlier
The A/B test variation changes only two words in the hook ('Keep your family's drinking water safe' vs. 'What's in your well water?'), which may not provide sufficiently distinct testing data

outputs.content:
**Caption Version A**
Unlock new funding for your land trust! Join "Grant Writing for Small Land Trusts" on Wednesday, February 12, 2025, 1:00–2:30pm CT via Zoom (online). Cost: $25 (members) / $45 (nonmembers).

This webinar is designed for staff and board members of small land trusts and conservation nonprofits. Learn to craft competitive proposals with strong outcomes and realistic budgets tailored to conservation work. Program Officer Dana Liu from @PrairieHorizonsFoundation will lead a live budget review and share sample narratives and scoring tips. Live auto-captions will be provided, the slide deck sent 24 hours in advance, and a recording will be available to all registrants.

Register today: https://mcea.org/events/grant-writing-webinar?utm_source=facebook&utm_medium=social&utm_campaign=grant_writing_webinar_feb25. Tap "Interested" or "Going" to stay updated! Early-bird pricing ends January 31. Limited to 200 participants.

#GrantWriting #Conservation #LandTrusts

**Caption Version B**
Transform your grant proposals! Join "Grant Writing for Small Land Trusts" on Wednesday, February 12, 2025, 1:00–2:30pm CT via Zoom (online). Cost: $25 (members) / $45 (nonmembers).

Tailored for staff and board members of small land trusts and conservation nonprofits, this session will empower you to craft competitive proposals with strong outcomes and realistic budgets. Featuring Dana Liu, Program Officer at @PrairieHorizonsFoundation, the webinar includes a live budget review, sample narratives, and invaluable scoring tips. Live auto-captions, advance slide decks, and recordings for registrants are included.

Secure your spot now: https://mcea.org/events/grant-writing-webinar?utm_source=facebook&utm_medium=social&utm_campaign=grant_writing_webinar_feb25. Mark yourself "Interested" or "Going"! Early-bird pricing ends January 31. Capacity is limited to 200.

#NonprofitGrants #EnvironmentalEducation #Fundraising

**Image suggestion**
A professional graphic with the event title "Grant Writing for Small Land Trusts," the MCEA logo, date (February 12, 2025), time (1:00–2:30pm CT), and the Zoom icon, all on a clean, nature-inspired background.

**Alt-text**
A graphic announcing "Grant Writing for Small Land Trusts" by MCEA on February 12, 2025, at 1:00–2:30pm CT via Zoom, visually promoting an online webinar for conservation professionals.

**Pinned first comment**
For any inquiries about the "Grant Writing for Small Land Trusts" webinar, please contact Jenna Park, Program Director, at training@mcea.org or call 312-555-0198. We look forward to helping you enhance your grant-seeking skills!

**Posting tips**
* Post 6–9am or 12–2pm local; adjust using your Facebook Insights for when your audience is most active
* Cross-post from the Facebook Event page and tag venue/partners to expand reach
* Monitor and reply to comments in the first hour to boost distribution

evaluation.reasoning: The output delivers professional, well-structured Facebook posts that match the formal tone requested and include most required elements. However, it misses the spokesperson sign-off explicitly provided in the input and could improve mobile optimization. The content is immediately usable with minor adjustments.
strengths: Excellent tone consistency - maintains formal, professional voice appropriate for a regional professional association throughout both versions
Strong hook variations - Version A uses benefit-driven 'Unlock new funding' while Version B uses action-oriented 'Transform your grant proposals', providing genuine A/B test value
Comprehensive accessibility details integrated naturally without overwhelming the post
UTM parameters correctly appended to registration links as requested
Appropriate emoji restraint (zero used) matching formal tone
Clear, actionable CTAs with Facebook-specific engagement prompts ('Tap Interested or Going')
Ethical urgency properly conveyed with truthful early-bird deadline and capacity limits
Image suggestion is practical and appropriate for a professional organization
Alt-text is descriptive and accessibility-focused
Hashtags are relevant, professional, and limited to 3
weaknesses: Missing spokesperson sign-off - Input specified 'Jenna Park, Program Director' but neither caption includes a signature line, violating the prompt requirement to include sign-off when spokesperson is provided

Mobile optimization could be improved - While essential details appear early, the first two lines exceed typical 'See more' cutoff (approximately 125 characters); could be tightened to ensure all What/When/Where/Cost appears before fold
Word count slightly over target - Both captions appear to exceed 150 words (approximately 155-160 words each)

**Caption Version A**

Spark creativity and connection at Family Day at the Grand Museum! 🎉
Sunday, May 4, 2025 | 10:00am–2:00pm | Grand Museum of Art, 455 Museum Way, Harbor City | Free with RSVP

This special day is for families with children ages 3–12, museum members, and the general public to enjoy hands-on art-making, exciting performances, and free museum admission. Explore studio stations, catch a youth dance performance at 11:30 am, and embark on a gallery scavenger hunt. The first 200 kids will receive art kits! We offer elevator access, a quiet/sensory-friendly hour from 10–11 am, and large-print guides. Caregivers must remain with children (no drop-off). Spanish and Mandarin volunteers will be at the welcome desk.

Ignite your family's imagination! RSVP today at https://harborcityarts.org/familyday and tap “Interested” or “Going” to stay updated.
RSVP required; art kits limited to first 200 kids.

@HarborCityTransit @GrandMuseumOfArt
#FamilyFun #HarborCityArts #GrandMuseum

Sunday, May 4, 2025 | 10:00am–2:00pm | Grand Museum of Art, 455 Museum Way, Harbor City | Free with RSVP

Explore studio stations, catch a youth dance performance at 11:30 am, and embark on a gallery scavenger hunt. The first 200 kids will receive art kits! #FamilyFun #HarborCityArts #GrandMuseum

Get ready for a fantastic day! Garage parking is validated up to 2 hours, and we’re near Metro Line A, Museum Way stop. Alicia Moreno, Director of Community Programs.

# CAPTION VERSION A

Spark creativity this Sunday with art, movement, and play for the whole family! 🎨

**Family Day at the Grand Museum | Sunday, May 4 | 10am–2pm**  
Grand Museum of Art, 455 Museum Way, Harbor City | Free with RSVP

Families with children ages 3–12 can explore hands-on studio stations, catch a youth dance performance at 11:30am, and embark on a gallery scavenger hunt. The first 200 kids receive free art kits!

Sensory-friendly quiet hour 10–11am. Elevator access and large-print guides available. Spanish and Mandarin volunteers at the welcome desk. Caregivers must stay with children.

Garage parking validated for 2 hours. Near Metro Line A, Museum Way stop.

**Reserve your spot:** https://harborcityarts.org/familyday  
Tap "Going" and bring your crew!

Art kits limited to first 200 kids. RSVP recommended.

@GrandMuseumOfArt @HarborCityTransit

#FamilyDay #HarborCityArts #FreeForFamilies

---

# CAPTION VERSION B

First 200 kids get free art kits—mark your calendar now! 🎨

**Family Day at the Grand Museum | Sunday, May 4 | 10am–2pm**  
Grand Museum of Art, 455 Museum Way, Harbor City | Free with RSVP

Families with children ages 3–12 can explore hands-on studio stations, catch a youth dance performance at 11:30am, and embark on a gallery scavenger hunt. The first 200 kids receive free art kits!

Sensory-friendly quiet hour 10–11am. Elevator access and large-print guides available. Spanish and Mandarin volunteers at the welcome desk. Caregivers must stay with children.

Garage parking validated for 2 hours. Near Metro Line A, Museum Way stop.

**Reserve your spot:** https://harborcityarts.org/familyday  
Tap "Going" and bring your crew!

Art kits limited to first 200 kids. RSVP recommended.

@GrandMuseumOfArt @HarborCityTransit

#FamilyDay #HarborCityArts #FreeForFamilies

---

# IMAGE SUGGESTION

Photo of children at a previous Family Day engaged in hands-on art-making at colorful studio tables, with families visible in the background exploring gallery spaces.

**Alt-text:** Children paint and create art projects at colorful tables during Family Day at Grand Museum, with families exploring galleries in background. Bright, welcoming community atmosphere.

---

# PINNED FIRST COMMENT

**What to expect:** Quiet/sensory-friendly hour 10–11am, youth dance performance at 11:30am, scavenger hunt, and studio stations throughout the day. Garage parking validated up to 2 hours; accessible via Metro Line A (Museum Way stop). Caregivers must remain with children. Questions? Contact events@harborcityarts.org or 415-555-2278.

---

# POSTING TIPS

• **Post 6–9am or 12–2pm** on Thursday or Friday before the event when parents are planning weekend activities
• **Create a Facebook Event page** first, then share from that event to amplify reach and enable the "Interested/Going" buttons
• **Reply to every comment in the first hour** (even a quick "See you there! 🎨") to boost the algorithm
• **Repost on Saturday morning** as a reminder with "Tomorrow!" language to capture last-minute planners
• **Tag @GrandMuseumOfArt and @HarborCityTransit** in the caption *and* as photo tags to trigger partner notifications and expand reach beyond your followers

The captions are well-structured, mobile-optimized, and include all essential details in the critical first two lines. Minor deductions for slight wordiness (pushing upper word limit) and repeating the art kit limitation twice in Version A.

Comprehensive accessibility information integrated naturally without feeling like a compliance checklist

Effective use of ethical urgency (art kit limitation) without creating false scarcity

Appropriate emoji restraint (only 2, both relevant) and hashtag selection (3, specific and searchable)

weaknesses: Caption Version A repeats the art kit limitation information twice (in body and at end), creating slight redundancy that could be streamlined

Missing the spokesperson sign-off despite 'Alicia Moreno, Director of Community Programs' being provided in the input—prompt specified to include signature when spokesperson is provided

The warm tone is appropriate for a family event, essential details appear before the fold, and the A/B test variation provides genuine value. Minor weaknesses include slight repetition and a word count that pushes the upper limit, but overall this would serve a nonprofit communications team well.
